By that you attain the great kingdom and are saved from the painful punishment. So contemplate the people of Paradise and in their faces the radiance of bliss. They are given to drink from a sealed pure wine, sitting on thrones of red ruby in tents of moist white pearl, therein spreads of green brocade, reclining on couches set up on the banks of rivers flowing with wine and honey, surrounded by youths and boys, adorned with wide-eyed houris of beautiful good deeds, as if they were ruby and coral. Upon her are fine white silks that bewilder the gazes, crowned with crowns studded with pearl and coral, shapely, coquettish, fragrant, secure from old age and misery, secluded in the tents in palaces of ruby built amidst the gardens of Paradise, with restrained glances, chaste. Then they are served, and upon them, with cups and ewers and a cup from a flowing spring, white, a delight for the drinkers. And there serve them servants and boys like hidden pearls, a reward for what they used to do, in a secure station, in gardens and springs, in gardens and a river, in a seat of truthfulness near an Omnipotent Sovereign. They look therein at the face of the Noble King, and the radiance of bliss has shone in their faces. No fatigue touches them, nor abasement, but rather honored servants, and with various gifts from their Lord they are attended. They are in what their souls (Nafs) desire, abiding forever; they do not fear therein, nor do they grieve, and they are secure from the doubt of death. They are therein enjoying themselves, and they eat from its foods and drink from its rivers milk and wine and honey, in rivers whose beds are of silver and whose gravel is coral, and on its ground its dust is fragrant musk and its vegetation is saffron. And they are rained upon from clouds therein from water of narcissus upon dunes of camphor. And they are brought cups, and what cups! With cups of silver studded with pearls and ruby and coral, a cup containing from the sealed pure wine mixed with it the sweet Salsabil, a cup whose light shines from the purity of its jewel, the drink appears from behind it with its thinness and redness. And whoever's aim is the Lord (Rabb) of the Abode (Al-Dar) and the Owner (Malik) of the Kingdom (Al-Mulk), and nothing overcomes him except his love (Hubb) with sincerity (Ikhlas) and truthfulness (Sidq), is settled "in a seat of truth (Maq'adi Sidq) near a Sovereign (Malik) All-Powerful (Muqtadir)." So the righteous (Al-Abrar) frolic in the gardens and enjoy bliss in the paradises (Al-Jinan) with the wide-eyed maidens (Al-Hur Al-'In) and the eternal youths (Al-Wildan), while the ones brought near (Al-Muqarrabun) are constant in the Presence (Al-Hadrah), devoted with their gaze upon it, considering the bliss of the paradises insignificant compared to an atom of it. For some people are preoccupied with satisfying the desire of the belly and the private parts, and for companionship there are other people. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Most of the people of Paradise are the simple-minded, and 'Illiyyun is for those of understanding." And when understandings fell short of grasping the meaning of 'Illiyyun, He magnified its matter, saying: "And what can make you know what 'Illiyyun is?" just as Allah the Exalted said: "The Striking Calamity - what is the Striking Calamity? And what can make you know what the Striking Calamity is?"
